ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned a lot about political comms and strategy, from both a historical and modern point of view.
I learned how to identify various methods of persuasion in politics. I was exposed to types of political communication that I did not know about prior to taking this course.

I learned persuasive techniques used in politics along with the ways that systems of politics have been manipulated in the past to reach specific outcomes. We looked at these topics within political parties, specific individuals, news and the media, and in campaigns.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Super interesting, not the highest workload, fun writing assignments. Discussions were engaging but not forced.

The readings for this course were excellent. I always came away from the readings with a solid understanding of what we would be discussing in class that week. The class discussions were also very engaging.

This course, being very discussion-heavy, fell victim to a bad room layout. It was tough to join in the conversation when sat at a long rectangular table and not having a chance to talk toor really physically seemany in the classroom. Nonetheless, Henderson did a fantastic job trying to facilitate conversation by having us play games with each other at times or prompting students with different opinions to work through them. This helped engage us and also allowed us to get closer with our peers, which further facilitated conversation. I feel at times that Henderson focused too much on giving context to the readings or quizzing us on them (of which there were many, some droning and unnecessary but others extremely riveting) instead of applying the lessons laid out in the readings to the modern day. I feel this class would also greatly benefit if it was a course that met twice a week for less time instead of a class that met once a week for around two hours.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely! Super interesting and Professor Henderson is great.
Yes! Professor Henderson is really nice and wants students to get a lot out of the class without forcing it. You'll learn a lot and put it into practice in cool ways.
I would absolutely recommend this course to anyone who is interested in political campaigns.

YES! Please take this course if you get the chance and are interested in campaigns, political persuasion, or the heresthetics of government. Though I think the course focused a little too much on history than it needed to, the things I learned in this class about persuasion and politics are things I will carry in my mind throughout my career. Henderson is also a wonderful professor with a sharp mind and experience in the field, making his insights ones that you truly wouldn't have access to outside of this course. I wish he would've given more wisdom to us.
